title: Will the US domestic box office gross in the opening weekend for Top Gun: Maverick reach or exceed $45 million, according to Box Office Mojo?
preds: Travel is expected to be back to 92% of pre pandemic levels and weather is expected to be temperate and fairly dry across the US outside of the Northern Plains and Upper Midwest.  If these things hold, it will lead to more people outside and less in movie theaters.  Tom Cruise's best movie openings have been rather low even when adjusted for inflation and while the biggest box office hits of the past year well exceed the $45m mark for opening weekend the promotion of this film appears to be limited.

Some of the toughest film critics I know are raving about the movie. One went as far as to call it "magnificent" and say "I adore this film."  Another called it "exciting in the air and efficient on the ground, adding that "less of a sequel than a renovation, infuses the 1986 drama of airborne combat with today’s politics" adding that the movie comes in as "an emblem of its benighted political times. That’s why, in comparison with the sequel, the original comes off as a work of warmhearted humanism. Yet, paradoxically, and disturbingly, “Maverick” is also a more satisfying drama, a more accomplished action film—I enjoyed it more..." It's one of the best reviewed movies so far this year. Not that well-reviewed films make it big in the box office but I think this adds to the probability that it will bring enough numbers of it's intended demographics back to the theatres so that the question would resolve as a yes.   Should also note the movie is trending on Twitter tonight and that is notable for a Thursday night and for any film.
news reports predict grossing $100M or more.  Drove by local theater early evening and saw the parking lot packed for the first time in two years.  it's a long weekend and people want to get out.

Here are the latest data & projections by BoxOfficePro: https://www.boxofficepro.com/weekend-box-office-forecast-top-gun-maverick-targets-tom-cruises-first-100m-opener-and-potential-memorial-day-records/ Quoting excerpts: --- Weekend Box Office Forecast: Top Gun: Maverick Targets Tom Cruise’s First $100M+ Opener and Potential Memorial Day Records Long range tracking has been nothing short of encouraging with models pushing its trajectory higher and higher.  Compounding the buzz are ecstatic reviews from critics and industry screenings over the past month as the film holds an incredible 97 percent Rotten Tomatoes score from 189 critics. Thursday and true weekend sales look strong. The holiday itself will inflate Sunday, and the film’s strong draw for a premium screen experience means average ticket prices are soaring. Buzz across the social media sphere is incredibly positive, although the X factor remains in how well a sequel to a 36-year-old film will immediately draw in younger audiences. Paramount is notably releasing Maverick as the widest theatrical launch in history at 4,732 locations this weekend, besting the prior opening weekend record of 4,725 by 2019’s The Lion King remake.  The studio is setting expectations at a conservative level with expectations of a $92 million four-day bow.  Opening Weekend RangesTop Gun: Maverick3-Day Opening Weekend Range: $120 — 145 million4-Day Opening Weekend Range: $143 — 177 million --- I have no serious reason to doubt the above data & analysis; and given that, comparably, the 45M bar of the question seems very low (less than half of the most conservative estimations), I am moving my forecast to 100%.

Pretty much all leading headlines in entertainment are now touting possibility of a $180 million opening and whether Tom Cruise could get his first $100 million opening weekend. But having seen how this buzz often gets generated before a premiere we should not take it a face value.  Looking at numbers for Memorial Day weekend 2021, A Quiet Place Part II brought in $57M (Paramount Pictures) followed by Cruella with $26M, and then Rava and the Last Dragon, Wrath of Man and Spiral or garnering less than $3 million each (top five grossing films last memorial day) (Using last year as a point of reference because US box office is still 40% below pre pandemic levels). Dr Strange has had such a strong opening and performance and is dominating the international box office. One would have to think if it can take a big enough bite out of the box office to bring Top Gun's numbers down. From the headlines we're seeing today and Paramount's marketing campaign, one would have to think that it won't, at least not to bring it lower than $45M.  Maverick has already been released in several countries since last weekend but it's only showing to top the box office in Italy. Dr. Strange is dominating most markets by a lot. Numbers for most markets for Top Gun are either not available or had a very limited engagement in theatres and are thus not being counted yet. Can't see numbers for the UK where it had it's gala premiere.  Increasing forecast based on range of marketing campaign, and on amounts expected and already seen on weekend box office in the US in the last 2-3 months.

maintaining forecast - but some long-term boxoffice forecast info is predicting between 95 and 130 million over 3 day weekend and its coming out on memorial day weekend - https://www.boxofficepro.com/long-range-box-office-forecast-top-gun-maverick-and-bobs-burgers/#:~:text=Long%20Range%20Box%20Office%20Forecast%3A%20Top%20Gun%3A%20Maverick,%20Paramount%20Pictures%20%202%20more%20rows%20

I should be more realistic than my 100% guess and provide some rationale.  Strong rotten tomatoes score, well executed marketing, big star, holiday weekend, no obvious competition. Lots of reasons to be optimistic and $45M isn’t that high of a bar.   COVID wave and the fact that the original fans are in their 50s+ is a small negative. In my experience the original defies generations though.   I would predict $100M+. I might even give a small shot at a $200M opening weekend.

Buzz and trailer for Mission Impossible, which opens in July 2023, is getting a lot more traction on social media today than Top Gun following the Cannes buzz. 
 Google search results for Top Gun started to spike on April 24, peaked for the Cannes premiere, went down by half and started to pick up again. The movie soundtrack (Lady Gaga) has 16 million views on Youtube. The first trailer got 24 million views on Youtube but most recent clips barely make it to 100,000 views.
 The trailer for the top grossing film this past weekend, Dr Strange, garnered 55 million views in comparison and other clips for that same movie got 1-3 million. 
 But looking at opening weekend box office performance for other movies in mid-lower box office range this year, movies like Death on the Nile, Northman, Uncharted, Lost City with relatively less star power/budget, none cut the $45M mark (Uncharted came close).  Three day holiday weekends tend to draw significantly larger numbers to movie theatres and that increases the odds but not confident on this one.

Maverick had its opening at Cannes this past week where it received a 5 min standing ovation.. Most reviews are positive, with some even calling it better than the original. Of course star power plays a big part and it was the biggest premiere of the festival, adding the hype of an almost fully normal Cannes.  There's a good piece in the WSJ today that makes some good points as to why this film is such a big bet/risk: It's been 36 years since the original movie came out. Release date was delayed four times since 2020 because of the pandemic and it's being released now that the box office is making a good recovery with movies like Spiderman, Batman, Dr Strange, Sonic doing really well.  But the box office overall is still 40% below pre pandemic level. The movies that have performed the best in the past two years have come from "established franchises in the superhero genre" This means "uncertainty for a movie with a prequel from the cold war era" The audience that saw the first movie is almost 50 now and that's a demographic that has not yet returned to theatres. So expectations are not as high as they were for the first movie, which was the top grossing film the year it came out (1986).  BoxOffice Pro projects that Maverick will make between $280-$395 million total domestically and the plans for the studio are to run it longer than the actual 45 days that movies stay in theatres before moving to streaming now.  This may mean that they are not so sure about a huge opening week but that rely more on the movie increasing its audience.  Maverick will have to prove that it appeals to a younger audience beyond the 45-50 crowd. "More than half of people over 45 yrs old have not been to a movie theatre in the past year, compared to 20% between 18-24."  That said, the movie is picking a great weekend to open in the US and there are no other big films opening that weekend that could compete with Paramount's marketing. Covid numbers are increasing (they're in fact 4 times the number of cases that we had last year at this time) but people don't seem to mind (except when it comes to returning to the office).  I'm lowering the odds based on Paramount planning for an extended run vs the average movies get before hitting streaming.
Very positive reviews.  Also think that all the negative sentiment around Russia and Ukraine could be offset by positive support for Top Gun as an antidote to that sentiment.

Base rate is about 30% chance to exceed $45M (based on BoxOfficeMojo's top 1000 films opening weekend sales). Intuitive judgement is that there is a 100% chance to exceed $45M. Assuming r=0.65 (which is very generous) based on the amount of budget and time put into advertising the film (admittedly this "r" value is just an estimation on my part) I end up with about 76% chance to exceed $45M. In other words, I'm estimating that this will be in the top 24% of the 1000 films (ranked by opening weekend) on BoxOfficeMojo and will earn more than $52M. https://www.boxofficemojo.com/chart/top_opening_weekend/

I have done nothing more scientific than scan the list here (https://www.boxofficemojo.com/chart/top_opening_weekend/) and think that there are a lot of films that had much less hype that made $45m on the opening weekend, plus note the relatively high number of sequels in the list.

Although I made the point that the Top Gunn had over 21 million views, now I have come to the realization that the majority of people most likely didn’t take watching the commercial intentionally or seriously. YouTube tends to recommend certain videos to certain people, so watchers could’ve intentionally, however, probably not everyone who “watched” the trailer viewed the entire thing. Additionally, we’re not sure if people viewed the video twice so there could be a lot of viewers that viewed it more than once. I also wanted to come to the realization that although $9.57 is the average it doesn’t mean that every person who viewed it that weekend paid the price the average says they would pay. Children or people under the age of 18 have to be counted. However, these are all minor things, and that is why I decided to narrow the percentage only by 5% and I’m still confident that it’ll reach the $40 million mark.

Cruise missile of 27 July 2018, made 61.236mn (or 27.8% of total) on the opening weekend from 4,386 theaters. https://www.boxofficemojo.com/release/rl2449573377/ Numbers ("Average", "Opening") are pretty consistent across Paramount Picture movies; if "Top Gun: Maverick" makes ~16mn to 17mn USD on the first day and attendance  again does not drop off before 7 to 10 days after release, gross should be comparable to "Mission : Impossible - Fallout" (2018) even with a 26% discount due to COVID-19/omicron capacity losses, given all other releases of 27 May 2022 are supposed to be limited releases only [ https://www.boxofficemojo.com/calendar/?ref_=bo_nb_tt_tab ]. The reason May 2022 ranks #29 only among all months "May" so far can be explained by (i) the stat containing only one third or less of a full month and (ii) only 52 releases in total have been registered month-to-date this year, compared to e.g. a total of 218 releases in May 2018 ($1,040,414,433 for the full month of May 2018). https://www.boxofficemojo.com/chart/top_grossing_month/?by_occasion=may&ref_=bo_csm_ac Carrying forward the to-date figures shows that 2022 can likely compete with other Top10 "top grossing Mays" and, including the assumed "Top Gun : Maverick" impact, is likely to end up around 1.0bn USD from 150 releases. The surprisingly high interest in "Doctor Strange in the Multiverse of Madness" [ https://www.boxofficemojo.com/release/rl3724903937/?ref_=bo_ml_table_1 , contibuting a cumulative 201,041,558USD from Fri, 06 through Mon, 09 May 2022 alone] speaks for a "return of block buster movies", a category which certainly fits a sequel of "Top Gun".

Do I think the sequel can get 11% of that performance opening weekend? Absolutely.

The average weekend box office gross figures (adjusted for inflation) of memorial day openings from 1997 to now are over $65 million. Top Gun was the most famous movie of its time, in the genre of course, and reboots and late sequels have been highly sought after in past years. The projected figures of the movie have been seen as anything from $95 million to $130 million, but nowhere near $45 million. Covid would have been a factor, however Spider-man: No Way Home, made $260 million proving that the pandemic is a much smaller factor now than it has been in past years. The ad budget for the movie is over $140 million and they have spent $150 million on production of the movie. On top of that, every scene in a jet was shot in the cockpit of an actual F/A-18 Super Hornet, something that has never been done. Tom Cruise is a huge name in Hollywood and he is complimented by actors such as Jon Hamm, Val Kilmer, Miles Teller, Ed Harris, and Glen Powell. With an all star cast, a massive budget on both production and advertising, an abundance of hype and nostalgia, and a great potential for a plot, Top Gun Maverick is destined for much more than $45 million.

The movie is highly anticipated, early reviews are great, and it has no real competition on release (Dr. Strange releases 3 weeks earlier). Also, almost all movies released on Memorial Day weekend surpass 45M$ in revenue in the first weekend. it was reported the film has already sold over $42 million worth of advance ticket sales in North America https://www.boxofficepro.com/long-range-box-office-forecast-top-gun-maverick-and-bobs-burgers/ so 45M$ on opening should be a slam-dunk.
The analysis that @Feyy left makes sense to me.

Over 200 films have broken the $45M opening weekend barrier, including half a dozen Tom Cruise vehicles. The 2nd highest opening was Spider-Man: No Way Home which occurred during peak omicron scare, so the pandemic is not an obstacle. Top Gun is also a famous film with an built-in fanbase. Considering (1) the trailer was released in 2020 and anticipation has been building for over two year and (2) Cruise's apparent ability to keep any current-day politics out of his films, thus avoiding any audience division (compare receipts for Eternals or Black Widow with No Way Home for the difference politics can make) then barring another lockdown (unlikely, we're entering summer), I can't see this not happening.
